Initial comments:This report is the result of an unannounced onsite complaint investigation (CHL23C952S) completed on December 20 - 22, 2023, at Geisinger Wyoming Valley Outpatient Surgery CenterPoint.  It was determined the facility was not in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Ambulatory Care Facilities, Annex A, Title 28, Part IV, Subparts A and F, Chapters 551-573, November 1999. The state investigation was initiated on December 20, 2023.  It was identified a federal investigation was warranted.  CMS was contacted and a federal investigation was approved on December 21, 2023.   Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of an unannounced onsite complaint investigation (CHL23C952S) completed on December 20 - 22, 2023, at Geisinger Wyoming Valley Outpatient Surgery CenterPoint.  It was determined the facility was not in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Ambulatory Care Facilities, Annex A, Title 28, Part IV, Subparts A and F, Chapters 551-573, November 1999. The state investigation was initiated on December 20, 2023.  It was identified a federal investigation was warranted.  CMS was contacted and a federal investigation was approved on December 21, 2023.   Plan of Correction: 553.12 (b)(7) LICENSURE Implementation:553.12	(b) The following are the minimal provisions for the patient's bill of rights: 		(7) The patient has the right to good quality care and high professional standards that are continually maintained and reviewedObservations:Based on review of facility documents, medical record (MR) and staff interview (EMP), it was determined the facility failed to ensure operating room personnel did not prepare a patient's surgical site with a documented allergy to ChloraPrep for one of one applicable medical record reviewed (MR1). Findings include:Review on December 21, 2023, of the facility's "Patient rights & responsibilities" brochure, dated June 2021, revealed "... Care delivery You or your legally authorized representative or guardian have the right to: ... Receive efficient and quality care with high professional standards that are continually maintained and reviewed. Expect good management techniques to be implements within this hospital considering effective use of your time and to avoid your personal discomfort ..."Review on December 21, 2023, of the facility's "Amended and Restated Bylaws of the Medical Staff of Geisinger Wyoming Valley Medical Center Bylaws of the Medical Staff," last approved by the Board of Directors on September 21, 2022, revealed "... Article II Purpose and Responsibilities ... Section 2.2 Responsibilities ... The responsibilities of the Medical Staff are: (a) to account for the professional performance, ethical conduct and appropriateness of patient care rendered by all Practitioners ... Article III Medical Staff Membership ... Section 3.3 Basic Responsibilities of Staff Membership Each member of the Medical Staff shall: (a) Provide his patients with care that is consistent with generally recognized standards of professional performance and efficiency ..."  Review on December 21, 2023, of the facility's "Geisinger Wyoming Valley Outpatient Surgery CenterPoint Patient Safety Program and Plan", last approved February 8, 2023, revealed "Purpose Geisinger Wyoming Valley Outpatient Surgery CenterPoint (GWV OSCP) is dedicated to creating, supporting, and disseminating a culture of safety throughout the organization. ..."Review on December 21, 2023, of the facility's "Universal Protocol - System Policy," last approved July 22, 2021, revealed "... Policy By ensuring that systems are in place, the following steps, taken together, comprise the Universal Protocol for eliminating wrong site, wrong procedure and wrong person surgery or procedures. ... Responsibilities The attending surgeon or individual performing the procedure oversees the Universal Protocol process. The entire OR/procedural team actively participates in the Time-Out ... Procedure I. Applicability The Universal Protocol is applicable to all invasive procedures as defined above ... II. Mandatory The Universal Protocol includes 3 mandatory elements: pre-procedure verification, marking of the site (see exceptions), and time out. ... III. Pre-Procedure Verification Pre-procedure verification consists of 3 parts: Verification of patient ID, verification of correct site/procedure and verification of available special equipment (implants, etc.), blood products, medications (antibiotics), as required for the patient. A. Verification of patient identification must be completed by utilizing 2 patient identifiers and the consent form. B. Verification of correct site/procedure must be completed by utilizing the correct patient's H&P/office notes, pre-anesthesia evaluation, diagnostic studies including radiology and/or pathology reports, and a properly completed and signed consent form ...VI. Documentation of Universal Protocol A. Primary procedure(s) in the OR: 1. The pre-op nurse shall document in the patient's medical record that the site was marked by the attending surgeon. Operative / Procedure Reports An operative/procedure report should include date of procedure, description of procedure, a preoperative diagnosis, post operative diagnosis, name of procedure, name of primary surgeon and assistants, type of anesthesia, drains, estimated blood loss, specimens removed, disposition of each specimen, complications, condition of patient, and signature by the surgeon who performed the surgery/procedure. ..."Interview with EMP1 and EMP2 on December 20, 2023, at 1500 revealed it is the physician's responsibility to notify the patient and / or responsible party regarding harm or potential harm to a patient that occurs pre-operatively, intraoperatively, and post operatively.Review of MR1 on December 20, 2023, revealed documentation by CF1, CF2, EMP2 and EMP6 indicating this patient's allergy to ChloraPrep causing severe blistering.Interview with EMP1 and EMP2 on December 21, 2023, at approximately 1015 confirmed CF1, CF2, EMP2 and EMP6 were operating room (OR) staff present in the room for MR1's prep of this patient's surgical site and for MR1's surgical procedure. Review of MR1 on December 20, 2023, revealed this patient presented to Geisinger Wyoming Valley Centerpoint for a scheduled Arthroscopically Aided ACL (Anterior Cruciate Ligament - a structure that stabilizes the knee joint and prevents forward movement) surgical procedure of the left knee on September 6, 2023, at 1007.  Further review revealed EMP6 completed a surgical scrub with ChloraPrep to MR1's left knee.There was no documentation in MR1 indicating CF1 disclosed the use of ChloraPrep surgical prep on this patient to the patient or this patient's responsible party. Interview with EMP1, EMP2, EMP3 and EMP4 on December 21, 2023, at approximately 0945 confirmed the above information. Review of MR1 on December 20, 2023, revealed this patient presented to an Outside Hospital (OSH) Emergency Department (ED) on September 9, 2023, with complaint of large fluid filled blisters located around the incision sites and had multiple blisters already erupted with clear / yellow fluid draining from the erupted blisters. MR1 was treated with intravenous Decadron (a medication that reduces swelling and to treat severe allergic reactions) 10 milligrams (mg) / Milliliter (ml) at 1517 and an order to take Benadryl orally when at home.Interview with EMP1, EMP2, EMP3 and EMP4 on December 21, 2023, at approximately 0950 confirmed the above information. Review of MR1 on December 21, 2023, revealed an addendum made by CF1 on September 15, 2023, at 1324 indicating after positioning the patient and leaving the room to scrub, OR nursing inadvertently applied ChloraPrep to the operative extremity despite a previous allergy and blister reaction. MR1 was treated with intravenous Decadron (a medication that reduces swelling and severe allergic reactions) 10 milligrams (mg) / Milliliter (ml) at 1517 and an order to take Benadryl orally when at home. Interview with EMP1, EMP2, EMP3 and EMP4 on December 21, 2023, at approximately 1000 confirmed the above information. Cross reference553.12 (b)(7) Implementation 555.1 Medical Staff Principle Plan of Correction - To be completed: 02/01/2024The facility medical director is responsible for this action plan. On 12-28-2023 facility and system leadership met to review the disclosure process. The team discussed and reviewed the Disclosure of Adverse Events and Errors: Guidelines. The clinical staff will be educated on the current guidelines by January 31, 2024. Per current guideline, a healthcare provider will disclose when a known allergen is given or applied and document the patient response.The medical director of the Outpatient Surgical CenterPoint will be notified of any incidents concerning known allergens given to or applied to patients identified via the current electronic reporting system. The identified chart will be audited to ensure the disclosure to patient was completed and documented correctly. The audit will continue for three months until 100% compliance is maintained. The OSCP medical director will meet 1:1 with any provider identified as noncompliant for education. To decrease the potential of future incidents, an electronic communication was developed and dispersed to all clinical staff within the health system on the importance of proper documentation. The communication included a review of current disclosure guidelines. The electronic communication was dispersed to all medical staff within the healthcare system. The information is also to be reviewed at system service line staff meetings and patient safety committee.

Initial comments:This report is the result of a State licensure survey conducted on-site on June 27, 2023, and off-site on June 28, 2023, at Geisinger Wyoming Valley Outpatient Surgery CenterPoint.  It was determined the facility was not in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Ambulatory Care Facilities, Annex A, Title 28, Part IV, Subparts A and F, Chapters 551-573, November 1999.  Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of a State licensure survey conducted on-site on June 27, 2023, and off-site on June 28, 2023, at Geisinger Wyoming Valley Outpatient Surgery CenterPoint.  It was determined the facility was not in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Ambulatory Care Facilities, Annex A, Title 28, Part IV, Subparts A and F, Chapters 551-573, November 1999.  Plan of Correction: 553.3 (1) LICENSURE Governing Body Responsibilities:553.3 	Governing Body responsibilities include: 		(1) Conforming to all applicable Federal, State, and local laws.Observations:Based on a review of facility policy, facility documentation and interview with staff (EMP), it was determined that the facility was not in compliance with the following state law: The Geisinger Wyoming Valley Outpatient Surgery CenterPoint was not in compliance with the following state law:   Findings include:"Act 13 of 2002MEDICAL CARE AVAILABILITY AND REDUCTION OF ERROR (MCARE) ACT"Section 310. Patient safety committee.(2) An ambulatory surgical facility's or birth center's patient safety committee shall be composed of the medical facility's patient safety officer and at least one healthcare worker of the medical facility and one resident of the community served by the ambulatory surgical facility or birth center who is not an agent, employee or contractor of the ambulatory surgical facility or birth center.  No more than one member of the patient safety committee shall be a member of the medical facility's board of governance.  The committee shall include members of the medial facility's medical and nursing staff.  The committee shall meet at least quarterly.Based on a review of facility documents, Patient Safety Committee meeting minutes and staff interview (EMP), it was determined the facility failed to ensure the Patient Safety Committee meetings were held quarterly. Findings include:Review on June 27, 2023, of the facility's "Geisinger Wyoming Valley Outpatient Surgery CenterPoint Patient Safety Program and Plan" policy, approved April 26, 2022, revealed "Purpose ... The purpose of the patient safety plan is to provide a framework for the implementation of various components of the patient safety program at GWV OSCP ...Policy ... Compliance with regulatory and accreditation requirements ...Patient Safety Committee ...Meeting Frequency - The Patient Safety Committee will meet quarterly ..."Review on June 27, 2023, of the Department of Health (Department) reports, revealed the Department completed an initial licensure and occupancy survey on October 7, 2022.Review on June 27, 2023, of the facility's Patient Safety Committee meeting minutes revealed no documentation the facility met in the fourth quarter of 2022. Interview with EMP1, EMP3 and EMP4 on June 27, 2023, at approximately 1015 confirmed the findings noted above. Plan of Correction - To be completed: 08/11/2023PolicyGeisinger Wyoming Valley Outpatient Surgery CenterPoint's Patient Safety Program and Plan policy, approved April 26, 2022, was reviewed and no revisions were made.EducationThe Director of the Ambulatory Surgical Center (ASC) will educate the Patient Safety Committee members on the Outpatient Surgery's Patient Safety Program and Plan" with a focus on the required frequency of Patient Safety Committee meetings. This education will be completed on July 19, 2023, at the ASC Operations Meeting, Performance Improvement Committee on July 18, 2023, and the Patient Safety Committee members on August 8, 2023. This education is evidenced by attendance sheets and meeting minutes for each meeting.Monitoring Meeting invitations were sent for the calendar year for the quarterly Patient Safety Committee Meetings to all committee members. Audits will be done quarterly by the Operations Director to ensure the Safety committee meeting occurs as scheduled on a quarterly basis. Meeting minutes will be documented to reflect the quarterly meeting requirement. This monitoring will continue until compliance is at 100% for three quarters and then a random audit will be completed to ensure ongoing compliance. Data will be forwarded to the Regulatory Performance Improvement Committee on a quarterly basis. Any noncompliance will be sent ASC Performance Improvement Committee as appropriate. Responsibility partyDirector of Ambulatory Surgical Center 553.21 (a) LICENSURE Admission, Transfer & Discharge - Principle:553.21 Principle 	(a) Written policies for admission, discharge, transfer and proper referral of patientsObservations:Based on review of facility documents, and staff interview (EMP), it was determined the facility failed to ensure the facility's written discharge policy met all the required criteria for a patient's discharge from the Ambulatory Surgical Facility (ASF).Findings include: Review of the facility's "Discharge Criteria" policy, last approved July 8, 2022, revealed "Purpose To establish guidelines for the post-anesthesia care RN for discharge from the Post operative area to home ...Policy To ensure all post-anesthesia patients are discharged properly ... Responsibilities It is the responsibility of the anesthesiologist to assess patient prior to discharge from the unit and to ensure all discharge criteria are met ..."There is no documentation the facility's "Discharge Criteria" policy included an assessment indicating the patient's bleeding is controlled and consistent with that expected from the surgical procedure prior to discharge from the ASF. Interview with EMP1 on June 28, 2023, at approximately 1430 confirmed the facility's "Discharge Criteria" policy did not include an assessment indicating the patient's bleeding is controlled and consistent with that expected from the surgical procedure prior to discharge from the ASF. Cross reference 553.25 (1-6) Discharge Criteria Plan of Correction - To be completed: 08/11/2023PolicyGeisinger Wyoming Valley Outpatient Surgery CenterPoint's "Discharge Criteria" policy, approved July 8, 2022, was revised July 12, 2023, to meet all required criteria to include an assessment indicating the patient's bleeding is controlled and consistent with the surgical procedure prior to discharge from the Ambulatory Surgical Facility (ASF).EducationThe Director of the Ambulatory Surgical Center (ASC) will educate ASF Nursing staff and providers on the Outpatient Surgery's Discharge Criteria policy and its revisions to include patient's bleeding. This education will completed on July 19, 2023, at the ASF Operations meeting evidenced by attendance sheets and meeting minutes, as well as an email with email receipts to all surgeons who have privileges at the ASF.Monitoring The Director of the Ambulatory Surgery Center and/ or designee will complete 50 chart audits per month to ensure compliance with documentation This audit will continue until compliance is at 100% for three months and then random tracers will be conducted to ensure on-going compliance. Data will be forwarded to the Regulatory PI Department and reviewed at Quality and the ASF Performance Improvement Committee as appropriate. Responsibility partyDirector of Ambulatory Surgical Center 553.25 (1-6) LICENSURE Discharge Criteria:  553.25  Discharge  Criteria	A patient may only be discharged from an ASF if the following physical status criteria are met:		(1) Vital signs.	Blood pressure, heart rate, temperature and respiratory rate are within the normal range for the patient's age or at preoperative levels for that patient.		(2) Activity.	The patient has regained preoperative mobility without assistance or syncope, or function at his usual level considering limitations imposed by the surgical procedure.		(3) Mental status.	The patient is awake, alert or functions at his preoperative mental status.		(4) Pain.		The patient's pain can be effectively controlled with medication.		(5) Bleeding.	Bleeding is controlled and consistent with that expected from the surgical procedure.		(6) Nausea/vomiting.	Minimal nausea or vomiting is controlled and consistent with that expected from the surgical procedure.Observations:Based on review of medical records (MR) and staff interview (EMP), the facility failed to ensure patients met the required discharge criteria prior to discharge for 20 of 20 medical records reviewed (MR1 through MR20).  Findings include:Interview with EMP1 on June 28, 2023, at approximately 1430 confirmed the facility's "Discharge Criteria" policy did not include an assessment indicating the patient's bleeding is controlled and consistent with that expected from the surgical procedure prior to discharge from the ASF. Review of MR1 through MR20 on June 28, 2023, revealed these patients had procedures performed at the surgery center in June 2023.There was no documentation in MR1 through MR20 indicating the facility assessed these patients for bleeding prior to discharge from the facility.Interview with EMP1, EMP2, EMP3 and EMP4 on June 27, 2023, at the time of the medical record reviews, confirmed the findings noted above for MR1 through MR20.  Cross reference 553.21 (a) Principle - Admission, Transfer & Discharge Plan of Correction - To be completed: 08/11/2023PolicyGeisinger Wyoming Valley Outpatient Surgery CenterPoint's "Discharge Criteria" policy, approved July 8, 2022, was revised July 12 2023, to meet all required criteria to include an assessment indicating the patient's bleeding is controlled and consistent with the surgical procedure prior to discharge from the Ambulatory Surgical Facility (ASF).EducationThe Director of the Ambulatory Surgical Center (ASC) will educate the ASF Nursing staff and providers on the Outpatient Surgery's Discharge Criteria policy and its revisions to include patient's bleeding. The education also included the assessment prior to discharge must be documented in the medical record and include that the bleeding is controlled. The assessment of bleeding upon discharge will be documented in the physician's discharge note.  This education will be completed on July 19, 2023, at the ASF Operations meeting evidenced by attendance sheets and meeting minutes, as well as an email with email receipts to all surgeons who have privileges at the ASF. Monitoring The Director of the Ambulatory Surgery Center and/ or designee will complete 50 chart audits per month to ensure compliance with documentation regarding the required discharge criteria.This audit will continue until compliance is at 100% for three months and then random tracers will be conducted to ensure on-going compliance. Data will be forwarded to the Regulatory PI Department and reviewed at the ASF Performance Improvement Committee as appropriate. Any noncompliance will be addressed by the service line director as well as medical director as necessary.
